p: Species Enterovirus A are classified within the genus Enterovirus, one of the more than 30 genera in the family Picornaviridae, which also includes the related human viral pathogens within the Hepatovirus, Parechovirus, and Kobuvirus families [ 10]. Members of the Picornaviridae family have non-enveloped, 30–32 nm icosahedral capsids containing 60 tightly-packed protomers which are highly stable under acidic conditions allowing virions to survive exposure to gastric acid, disinfectants and remain infectious at ambient room temperature for several days [ 11]. The positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genomes, ranging from 6.7 to 10.1 kb in size, possess 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions (UTRs) and encode a single polyprotein from which all viral gene products are processed by viral proteases [ 10, 12]. The proteins encoded in the enteroviral genome are organized from 5′ to 3′ with up to four structural capsid proteins followed by seven nonstructural proteins [ 10, 12].
